body: Agreed, I'm a +1 as well. Merged to main.

+1 everything still looks good, nice work!

One minor thing I noticed while doing another test... in the first import, there is no box to specify Comments for the first version, but there is Flow Description which is technically a different field for the overall versioned flow, then on future imports of additional versions there is a Comments field. I'm in no way saying to hold this up, just wanted to note it for future consideration.

> One minor thing I noticed while doing another test... in the first import, there is no box to specify Comments for the first version, but there is Flow Description which is technically a different field for the overall versioned flow, then on future imports of additional versions there is a Comments field. I'm in no way saying to hold this up, just wanted to note it for future consideration.

@bbende Do you propose adding a Comments box in the dialog for 'Import New Flow' (first version)? I can create a separate JIRA for this. Thanks.
Yes I think it makes sense to allow it. It would be consistent with Start Version Control from NiFi which has a Description and Comments field for the first version.

@ChrisSamo632, thanks for the contribution, this looks good to me. 
+1 I will merge when the builds finish

@ChrisSamo632 any reason that these methods are called `jsonEscape` and `jsonUnescape`? I think `escapeJson` and `unescapeJson` make more sense and would be more consistent with the existing conventions. For example, there already is a `Base64Decode`/`Base64Encode`, `PadLeft`/`PadRight`, etc.

@ChrisSamo632 wow. The example that I gave of `Base64Decode` does in fact match the convention you used :) Generally we would use <verb> <subject> though such as escapeJson, unescapeJson. Just like we do in Expression Language. It is odd that Base64Encode / Base64Decode does not follow that pattern, but I think that's an oversight.

Sorry, I realize it may seem like a bit of a quibble. But I definitely think that escapeJson / unescapeJson will be more intuitive for users. Especially since we already have an escapeJson / unescapeJson in Expression language. Reversing the order here I think would lead to a lot of confusion.

> @ChrisSamo632 wow. The example that I gave of `Base64Decode` does in fact match the convention you used :) Generally we would use though such as escapeJson, unescapeJson. Just like we do in Expression Language. It is odd that Base64Encode / Base64Decode does not follow that pattern, but I think that's an oversight.
> 
> Sorry, I realize it may seem like a bit of a quibble. But I definitely think that escapeJson / unescapeJson will be more intuitive for users. Especially since we already have an escapeJson / unescapeJson in Expression language. Reversing the order here I think would lead to a lot of confusion.

@markap14 no big deal - I'll change the names again (but leave the base64 functions along as that would obviously not be backwards compatible for any existing flows!)
@ottobackwards / @markap14 FYI - follow on from earlier PR
Updated PR to address latest feedback.
Here is the JIRA ([NIFI-8660](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-8660)) to allow adding Comments when importing a new flow.

@MikeThomsen Sorry, I worded that poorly. What I meant there was that the NPEs were introduced with the changes of NIFI-8502 and are fixed with this PR.

> I'm not sure to fully understand the difference between project ID and designate project ID. Can you give me an example to understand the difference on how resources will be used on the two projects?

Hi @pvillard31, thanks for your reply, the major purpose is that, when creating a job to load data of a project into BigQuery, this job will use the resources of the project. In most cases, a project can have data in BigQuery dataset and its limited resources for loading job. But in our cases, we split GCP projects into two layers for security control, data project and resource project: 
* Data project can only store data and provide data access, it doesn't have any resources to create any jobs. 
* Resource project is used to create jobs, users can only create job by resource projects instead of data project. 

That's the reason why we needs to config two project ID for BigQuery processors, the designate project ID is used to specify the target project to store data, and the other project ID is to specify the resource project.
@turcsanyip Thanks for the review, code modified according to your recomendations.

+1 LGTM, tried various scenarios with referencing components, verified the behavior is as expected (no deadlocks, e.g.). Thanks for the fix! Merging to main
Reviewing

Thanks for the improvement @naddym ! I think it makes a lot of sense to add in a Status Message property. Setting the flowfile content is often what we want for a "200 OK" type of response but this makes a lot of sense for other scenarios. The only thing that I'm not sure about is the idea of having this processor update the FlowFile content. I think it makes more sense to send back the use-configured response but not change the FlowFile. I can definitely see cases where we will want to receive an HTTP message, do something with it, then send back a response, and afterwards continue with the FlowFile to do something else. And in the case that we don't want to do anything and want to terminate the flow after HandleHttpResponse, there's no benefit to the overhead of updating FlowFile content.

So it seems to me that we should instead not have the processor update the FlowFile's content at all. But perhaps you have a different viewpoint that I'm missing?

Why not latest version of Avatica 1.18.0 ?
Avatica 1.18.0 fix one serious bug in NIFI-7601.

I have also submitted a PR for upgrading calcite to 1.27.0
here https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/5138

> Why not latest version of Avatica 1.18.0 ?
> Avatica 1.18.0 fix one serious bug in NIFI-7601.
> 
> I have also submitted a PR for upgrading calcite to 1.27.0
> here #5138

Thanks for the feedback @kent-nguyen!  These are transitive dependencies in hive-hcatalog-streaming, and version 1.6.0 appears to be the latest version for the dependency coordinates of org.apache.calcite:calcite-avatica.  I see a more recent version of 1.18.0 as you noted, but the Maven coordinates are different.  Unfortunately these Hive components have a number of very old dependencies, which makes management difficult.  The goal of this current PR is to update transitive dependencies enough to avoid third-party repositories, but in the long run, removing these legacy Hive components is probably the best way to go.
+1 LGTM, thanks for the upgrade! Merging to main
+1 LGTM, ran on a live system and executed the integration tests. The build failed because of an issue now fixed with #5142. Thanks for the fix! Merging to main

So was just doing a bit of testing, and I found that if you run ./bin/nifi.sh set-single-user-credentials <username> <password> with a different secure configuration (eg LDAP), the password/user will not be set. This is good, however it doesn't necessarily indicate that the command had no effect, it will still state "Login Identity Providers Processed". Otherwise, things are looking good.

> So was just doing a bit of testing, and I found that if you run ./bin/nifi.sh set-single-user-credentials with a different secure configuration (eg LDAP), the password/user will not be set. This is good, however it doesn't necessarily indicate that the command had no effect, it will still state "Login Identity Providers Processed". Otherwise, things are looking good.

Thanks for pointing that out @thenatog.  Do you think any changes are necessary in that case?  It seems that the command name `set-single-user-credentials` indicates what the command does, so unless the command should throw an error, I'm not sure what else should happen.
I would maybe expect to see a log saying "Single user provider cannot be used in conjunction with other identity providers."?

> I would maybe expect to see a log saying "Single user provider cannot be used in conjunction with other identity providers."?

That could be possible by evaluating the configured value from `nifi.properties` against the configured providers in login-identity-providers.xml, but it would involve some amount of additional handling just to produce an error message.  If you think it is worth doing, I can make the changes.
Okay no problem, I don't think it's worth it.
Thanks, @markap14 for the comments!

Good catch @markap14 Thanks. In case of `204 No Content` status code, the response outputstream is ignored and only headers are updated. However, make sense to allow property for empty string. I have made requested changes..

Though, looking at the rest of the nifi.properties, *.host appears to be the standard for everything except nifi.cluster.load.balance.address and nifi.cluster.node.address.  Perhaps these two should be renamed to nifi.cluster.load.balance.host and nifi.cluster.node.host.  Thoughts, @markap14, @exceptionfactory?

LGTM+1

Merged into main.
I just tested out running NiFi with a secure cluster and encrypting the configs/flow.xml to make sure everything was still operating functionally. The code and changes looks good to me. +1

Thanks for the update @exceptionfactory! Things are looking really good here! I did some testing and playing around with it and all works well. I'll do a code review and if all looks good merge.

Only thing I noticed was when I tried to set the password to something short like "pass" I got the following output:
```
Java home: /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/adoptopenjdk-8.jdk/Contents/Home
NiFi home: /Users/mpayne/devel/nifi/nifi-assembly/target/nifi-1.14.0-SNAPSHOT-bin/nifi-1.14.0-SNAPSHOT

Bootstrap Config File: /Users/mpayne/devel/nifi/nifi-assembly/target/nifi-1.14.0-SNAPSHOT-bin/nifi-1.14.0-SNAPSHOT/conf/bootstrap.conf

Password length less than required [12]
```
In that case, we have basically some debug output and then a failure message, but the failure message IMO wasn't as clear that it could be. It would be easy to miss the fact that it was a failure, and that could lead to a lot of confusion. So if all else looks good I'll update that message on merge to indicate "ERROR: " as a prefix so it's obvious. Otherwise, all looking great!
@exceptionfactory I'm going to do another pass through this today. Did you have any additional concerns or feedback on this?
All looks good @exceptionfactory. I've merged to main! Many thanks to @exceptionfactory for implementing this and to @thenatog @gresockj and @ChrisSamo632 for reviewing!

> @exceptionfactory I'm going to do another pass through this today. Did you have any additional concerns or feedback on this?

Thanks for asking @jfrazee, looks good from my perspective, feel free to merge if it looks good to you.

Ha I think `nifi.cluster.node.address` was the property I looked at to ensure the correct naming convention when I created the `nifi.cluster.load.balance.address` :(
Unfortunately, though, I don't think it's a good idea to rename. It could cause a lot of problems and confusion for people upgrading from one version to another. I think it makes more sense to just use 'address' in some places and 'host' in other places.

Honestly, though, @gresockj thinking about this a bit more - this PR updates the docs to match what the code does. I think perhaps we should go the other way. The documentation is all correct about what the property name should be. In the code, we just had a bug that caused it to look at the wrong property name. If we don't update the docs and instead just fix the bug in NiFiProperties, then we remain consistent with using `.host`, which I like. It means anyone who did go ahead and add in the extra property would need to ensure that in 1.14.0 that they do have the correct value for .host, but I think that's fair since the docs are already calling it out.

> Honestly, though, @gresockj thinking about this a bit more - this PR updates the docs to match what the code does. I think perhaps we should go the other way. The documentation is all correct about what the property name should be. In the code, we just had a bug that caused it to look at the wrong property name. If we don't update the docs and instead just fix the bug in NiFiProperties, then we remain consistent with using `.host`, which I like. It means anyone who did go ahead and add in the extra property would need to ensure that in 1.14.0 that they do have the correct value for .host, but I think that's fair since the docs are already calling it out.

I see your point.  I think it makes more sense the way you called out.  Updating the PR.

I'm not sure if your AttributeExpressionParser.g change did this, but in addition to `#{'test value'}` and `#{"test value"} `working, I noticed that `#{test value}` also works.  So, is the quote logic needed at all?

The only one of the above that works well with the UX is `#{test value}`, since this is what auto-completes and gives you the purple coloring.

Otherwise, functions as described.

We're marking this PR as stale due to lack of updates in the past few months. If after another couple of weeks the stale label has not been removed this PR will be closed. This stale marker and eventual auto close does not indicate a judgement of the PR just lack of reviewer bandwidth and helps us keep the PR queue more manageable.  If you would like this PR re-opened you can do so and a committer can remove the stale tag.  Or you can open a new PR.  Try to help review other PRs to increase PR review bandwidth which in turn helps yours.

Hi
When I typed in a fqdn as the nifi.cluster.load.balance.address is still bind to localhost. I had to type in the IP address or 0.0.0.0.
So the property name address seems to correspond to an actual ip address. If the property name was host I will assume it would be a fqdn.
If I have multiple network interfaces on my nodes, I would select one interface (ip address) to be the network for load balance and another for the remote access UI and S2S.
Using fqdn as host property will not provide you the possibility to select a different network for internal load balance between nodes. Therefore I will go for the address property and specified that it has to be an ip address
Kind Regards
Jens M. Kofoed

Thanks for the updates @turcsanyip! +1 Merging.

My only concern is https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-4427 but that seems like an edge case (users of QueryRecord that happen to use SUBSTRING), might be worth mentioning in the Release Notes / Migration Guide. Otherwise I'm good with the upgrade. Depending on when 1.28 is released (if before the NiFi 1.14 release) we should look at bumping it up again.
+1 LGTM, ran integration test and on a live system. Thanks for the fix! Merging to main
+1 LGTM, thanks for the fix! Merged to main
I misread this the first time around.  It works with ${#{'some value'}:toUpper()} with this PR and not with ${#{some value}:toUpper()}, as expected.  LGTM

Thanks @gschaer. I think took a look at the UI and played with it some. I can see some benefit in the ability to show/hide the grid. And I do like that the grid changes size as the user zooms in and out.

However, I find it a bit disorienting with the current sizes of the gridlines. They are quite a lot smaller than the old gridlines. It also means that with this update, all of the images in the User Guide, etc. all of our documentation are now out of date. I think it makes more sense to keep the size of the grid so that the gridlines are the same as they were before when zoomed into a 1:1 ratio (i.e., when you click the "Actual" button on the Navigate panel).

I'm also not really qualified to review the UI portion, as I have little experience with JavaScript / CSS so I'd like to see a committer who's done a lot of UI work review the UI code as well.

Is "Designate Project ID" a common formulation for BigQuery? If I understand correctly the new property would be used to define the project ID where the data will be loaded while the existing property is used to determine where the BigQuery "job" will be running to load the data and where associated costs will be charged. Correct?
